intro: Prosopis glandulosa subsp. torreyana, commonly known as the burro bush, is a shrub or small tree native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is characterized by its spiny stems and compound leaves that are often covered in glandular dots. The plant produces small, yellowish-green flowers that are followed by elongated, woody pods containing edible seeds. It is adapted to arid and semi-arid environments, making it drought-tolerant and suitable for xeriscaping. The species plays an important ecological role by providing habitat and forage for various wildlife species.
